Generate a story and a one short sentence as a title in the journalism style. For the story you generate put the title at the first row. The story should involves the following entities and summary. Please make sure the story you generate is at least 500 words long.

Yahoo Sports Videos Jim Boeheim was relieved of his head coaching duties a few hours after the Syracuse men's basketball team suffered defeat at the hands of a Wake Forest buzzer-beater in the ACC Tournament. After the game, Boeheim gave vague and opaque answers to questions about his future leading the program, and shortly after, the university announced he was being replaced by Adrian Autry. Twenty-year-old sensation Jenna Ortega is said to be securing a deal to star in director Tim Burton's “Beetlejuice 2.” The film is being written by Alfred Gough and Miles Millar, the showrunners of the hit Netflix series “Wednesday”—on which Burton is also […] NBC Sports Boston Celtics head coach Joe Mazzulla has a unique sleep technique, and he revealed the details to 98.5 The Sports Hub's "Zolak & Bertrand" show Wednesday.

Begin story:

Former Celtics Great Paul Pierce Stays Connected to the NBA through Buffalo Wild Wings, Showtime Basketball, and More

Camped out in his Los Angeles home, Paul Pierce's television is frequently programmed to NBA games. While some retired players turn away from the sport that once commanded their lives, Pierce has stayed attuned to the league he played in for 19 seasons, hosting friends for marquee matchups and ordering piles of chicken wings. “I put in a big order because we usually got friends over, and we're watching some hoops.”

Pierce will head to Houston next week for the first round of the NCAA tournament, watching games from inside a Buffalo Wild Wings alongside “All The Smoke” podcast hosts Stephen Jackson and Matt Barnes, plus two-time WNBA MVP A'Ja Wilson as part of an activation experience labeled “BnB-Dubs.” He has savored every avenue to remain connected to the sport, being part of the Showtime Basketball family after a run with ESPN.

“They've taken that maturity leap to finally take that next step and possibly be together for a long time and win multiple championships if healthy,” Pierce said, speaking of his former team, the Celtics. “There's a difference between older players telling you that behind the scenes and Charles being on national TV and everyone kind of airing out dirty laundry on podcasts.”

The retired NBA star has also been keeping an eye on the upcoming NBA draft and the potential prospects that could top the list. Inland California, Illinois, New Jersey and Delaware have the highest concentrations of the most-at-risk markets in the country, with the biggest clusters in the New York City and Chicago metropolitan areas, according to a report by Yahoo Sports.

As March Madness fills up our news feeds and online betting slips, Pierce reminisces on his own college basketball days. “I know it was 10 years ago now, but do you remember where you were on draft night 2013 when you got traded to Brooklyn?” he asked.

While Pierce may have left the Celtics and Brooklyn Nets, he still keeps tabs on the teams, including the recent addition of Frenchman Victor Wembanyama to the Nets. “The Blue Devils lost in the Elite Eight that season, but maybe they would have been champs if a long, athletic forward from Greece was on the team,” Pierce pondered.

As for the NBA playoffs, Pierce has his eye on the Phoenix Suns and the Boston Celtics, who both have strong rosters with players like Giannis, Kevin Durant, Jaylen, and Tatum. “It's going to be tough,” he said, “but that's what the NBA is all about.”

Pierce's connection to the NBA and basketball overall remains strong, even in retirement. Through various avenues like Buffalo Wild Wings and Showtime Basketball, he continues to stay involved in the sport that brought him so much success and joy.
